article_title: BCBSTX Proposes 20 Percent ACA Plan Cost Hike To Make Up $400 Million Loss « D Healthcare Daily
article_text:
The state’s largest insurer has announced plans to hike premiums on its Affordable Care Act plans to recoup a nearly $400 million loss it incurred last year because of Obamacare offerings.

CNBC reports that Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas brought in $2.1 billion in premiums, but paid out $2.5 billion in claims to that population. The insurance company revealed the loss in filings released by the Obama administration last week.

Blue Cross Blue Shield has requested the feds to OK about a 20 percent spike in premium costs, the station reports. This means that the 731,000 or so people enrolled in these ACA plans should expect to see anywhere from a 3 percent cut to a 20 percent hike, depending on whether the proposed rates go into effect. An estimated 8 of 10 BCBSTX plan holders qualify for federal subsidies at this moment, however.

Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas did not return a message requesting comment to D Healthcare Daily on Friday. CNBC quotes its parent company:

Lauren Perlstein, spokeswoman for the insurer’s parent, Health Care Service Corp., said the rate filings reflect the insurer’s “intention to offer an array of competitively priced products to existing and potential customers,” and that it has “gained a tremendous amount of experience, insight and data,” which was used to establish the rates. … Any discussion of average rate increases would be “misleading” because “rate changes individuals personally receive are impacted by a host of factors,” Perlstein added.

This wasn’t entirely unexpected. In January of 2014, Moody’s Investors Service downgraded the outlook for all the country’s health insurers to negative from stable.

“While we’ve had industry risks from regulatory changes on our radar for a while, the ongoing unstable and evolving environment is a key factor for our outlook change,” said Stephen Zaharuk, a Moody’s Senior Vice President said at the time. “The past few months have seen new regulations and announcements that impose operational changes well after product and pricing decisions were finalized.”

The Moody’s report then went on to predict the possibility that the premium costs from the young and (generally) healthy may not be enough to make up the costs of insuring the older and (generally) less healthy. At the time, 24 percent of enrollees were in that coveted 18-34 age range. Now, Health and Human Services figures put that at 28 percent. In order to fully offset the cost of treating the ill, that number, Moody’s says, would need to hover closer to 40 percent. Despite that being about 3.3 million people, it’s still not there yet.

Among other insurers in Texas, Cigna requested about a 16 percent increase for its local plus plan. Humana is waiting to see whether a 10 percent jump for its HMO will be approved. Smaller insurance plans seem to be struggling significantly more: Many of the Scott & White Health plans on the exchange have asked for close to a 100 percent increase on the premiums.

All health plans offered in Texas have requested some sort of increase. Peruse them here.
